The Bushmen of Botswana have won the right to go back home.
Botswana's high court has ruled that the government wrongly evicted hundreds of Bushmen from their ancestral hunting ground in the deserts of the southern African country.
The Bushmen claimed that the evictions, which began over a decade ago, were designed to allow diamond mining on their grounds in the Kalahari Desert.
Rupert Isaacson is a spokesman for the Indigenous Land Rights Fund, which supported the Bushmen's case.
The fact that they had been able to endure so many centuries of - to put an actual word on it - genocide, and win out at the end and come up with a ruling like this is just phenomenal.

Well that is certainly open to them now, given this verdict.

It took all day for the judgment to actually be delivered.
A lot of complex legal arguments and technology, but the result overall is that the Bushmen have won their case.
They are now free to return to their ancestral land inside the Kalahari and to resume their traditional lifestyle as hunter-gatherers.
The court ruled that the government of Botswana had acted illegally and unconstitutionally when it cut off the water supplies to the reserve and carried out the last round of evictions in 2002.

That it is an extraordinary outcome both for this ancient people and also for the government of Botswana itself, which was heavily criticized in the judgment of several of the actions that it took, including cutting off food supplies to those inside the reserve and also refusing hunting licenses.
Those measures were likened by one of the judges to sentencing the people inside the reserve to death by starvation.
There is mining, or at least mining exploration, taking place inside the Central Kalahari.

Well, the government had put forward a series of claims, most of which were not backed yesterday by the judges.
Principally, the government argued that the Bushmen were no longer living the traditional nomadic hunter-gatherer lifestyle.
As evidence for this, it pointed out the fact that they had for many years also been cultivating crops, and in some cases keeping livestock.
But the court decided that these were simply supplementary things that the Bushmen were doing to add to their main activity of hunting.
Now the government had also maintained that it was too expensive to provide services like water inside the reserve.
And that also the Bushmen were better off on the outside in resettlement villages, where they had easy access to schools and clinics and food and water were provided.
The basic government contention was that the Bushmen were in fact living in the past and needed to be moved into the modern world.
And for the Bushmen also, that was the core of the case.
They argued that they should have the rights to decide how and where they join the modern world.
